title: 107_hr2176
content: The "Disaster Burden Relief Act of 2001" allows for a credit for mortgage payments made on a destroyed home under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Disaster Burden Relief Act of 2001" provides a tax credit for payments made on acquisition indebtedness secured by a qualified destroyed home, which is defined as a residence substantially destroyed due to a declared disaster where the taxpayer's principal residence was affected. The "Disaster Burden Relief Act of 2001" offers a tax credit for payments on acquisition indebtedness secured by a qualified destroyed home, defined as a residence substantially destroyed by a declared disaster where insurance was unavailable at reasonable rates and not compensated for. Special rules apply, including coordination with interest deduction and credit only for payments due after destruction. The tax credit for payments on a destroyed home is reduced by any government grants received due to the destruction. The grant is allocated ratably over the remaining mortgage payment period. The taxpayer can elect not to have the credit apply. The taxpayer can elect not to have the credit apply for a taxable year. A clerical amendment is made to the tax code. Section 25B allows for mortgage payments on a destroyed home. Section 3 exempts income from the discharge of indebtedness on a destroyed home in presidentially declared disasters. Effective date for both sections is disasters occurring on or after January 1, 2000. SEC. 4 amends section 165 of the Internal Revenue Code to determine loss deduction on a destroyed home based on its fair market value before destruction. The amendment applies to disasters occurring on or after January 1, 2000. Amendment to section 165 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for loss deduction on the sale or exchange of a principal residence located in a disaster-affected area. Amendment to section 165 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for loss deduction on the sale or exchange of a principal residence located in a disaster-affected area, subject to certain conditions. Amendment to section 1211 of the Internal Revenue Code exempts certain losses from being subject to a specific rule. Effective from January 1, 2000, this amendment applies to sales and exchanges.
